msgSnippet: Also 3. Write tests when you need to figure out how something works to use it elsewhere.  This way, not only can you experiment without harming real code,
messageBody:
Also

3. Write tests when you need to figure out how something works to use it
elsewhere. This way, not only can you experiment without harming "real"
code, you leave a trail of your "experimental results" that future coders
can refer to and use.


Thanks
--DP

> Is this book out in the market?

It is available in e-book format from the publisher at
www.manning.com/rainsberger. It is available for order from Amazon, but
won't ship for another month or so.

> On a general note: Do you think it's worth writing JUnit test cases
> for all the classes present in legacy code. The number of class
> would be somewhere around 1000. If not, what areas do we need to
> concentrate to write test cases for?

General strategies:

1. Write tests only when you uncover a defect -- for each defect you
find, write a test that demonstrates the defect, then fix the defect.

2. Write tests only when you add new features. Write tests for the new
feature and for any legacy classes the new feature needs to use.

If you apply these two strategies repeatedly and faithfully, you'll test
the parts of the legacy system that need it most, and you'll spread out
the cost of adding tests over a longer period of time.
